appendix.title: &susemgr; Registration Client
appendix.para: Before you begin using &susemgr;, you must create a username, password, and System Profile. The &susemgr; Network Registration Client walks you through this process.

warning.para: After registering your system, refer to for instructions on starting the &susemgr; Update Agent.

sect1.screen: 0. enableProxyAuth No 1. noSSLServerURL http://xmlrpc.&exampledomain;/XMLRPC 2. oemInfoFile /etc/sysconfig/rhn/oeminfo 3. enableProxy No 4. networkSetup Yes 5. httpProxy 6. proxyUser 7. serverURL https://xmlrpc.&exampledomain;/XMLRPC 8. proxyPassword 9. debug No Enter number of item to edit <return to exit, q to quit without saving>:
sect1.para: Enter the number of the item to modify and enter a new value for the option. When finished changing your configuration, press to save your changes and exit. Press q and then to quit without saving your changes.

The most common options configured are enableProxy and httpProxy to enable a proxy server. To enable a proxy server, change the value for enableProxy to Yes and the value of httpProxy to the name of the proxy server and port number in the format HOST:PORT. For example, to use the proxy server squid.mysite.org on port 3128, you would change the value to squid.mysite.org:3128.

If you require a proxy username and password, set enableProxyAuth to Yes to enable username/password authentication for the proxy, and set proxyUser and proxyPassword to the appropriate username and password for the proxy.
To bypass SSL, change the protocol for serverURL from https to http in the /etc/sysconfig/rhn/rhn_register file.

sect1.title: Starting the &susemgr; Registration Client
sect1.para: You must be root to register a system with &susemgr;. If started by a standard users, the &susemgr; Registration Client prompts you to enter the root password before proceeding.

important.para: If your username is part of a larger organizational account, be cautious when registering your systems. By default, all systems registered with the &susemgr; Registration Client end up in the Ungrouped section of systems visible only to &susemgr; administrators. To ensure that you retain management of these systems, Red Hat recommends that your organization create an activation key associated with a specific system group and grant you permissions to that group. You may then register your systems using that activation key and find those system profiles within &susemgr; immediately. Refer to for instructions.

sect1.para: To start the &susemgr; Registration Client, use one of the following methods:

orderedlist.remark: toms 2011-01-31: Is it also possible with GNOME/KDE?

listitem.para: Type the command mgr_register at a shell prompt (for example an XTerm or GNOME terminal)
If you are not running the X Window System, type the command mgr_register at a shell prompt. Refer to for further details.

sect1.para: If you have already registered your system and try to register it again, a dialog box appears. If you continue, it overwrites your existing digital certificate file (/etc/sysconfig/rhn/systemid), and creates a different system profile. You will no longer be able to use your previous system profile â€” be sure this is what you want to do before you choose Yes.

The opening screen for the &susemgr; Registration Client provides a brief overview of the services available and the steps required to register (see ). Click Next to continue with the registration process. If you click Cancel, the registration process ends and no information is sent.

&novell; is committed to protecting your privacy (see ). The information gathered during the registration process is used to create a system profile. The system profile is essential if you wish to receive update notifications about your system.

sect1.title: Registering a User Account
sect1.para: Before you can create a system profile, you must create a user account. The only required information in this section is a unique username, password, and a valid email address.

In the screen shown in , you must choose a username and password. Once logged in to &ncc;, you can modify your preferences, view your existing system profile, or obtain the latest software packages. You must choose a unique username. If you enter one already in use, you will see an error message (see ). Try different usernames until you find one that has not been used.

note.para: If you are already a member of &novell;, you can use the same user name and password. However, you must continue with the registration process to create your system profile.

sect1.para: Your username has the following restrictions:

listitem.para: Is not case-sensitive, thereby eliminating the possibility of duplicate usernames differing only by capitalization

sect1.para: In addition, the following restrictions apply to both your username and password:

listitem.para: Must be at least four characters long

sect1.para: Passwords are case-sensitive for obvious reasons.

If you have already registered a machine and created a system profile, you can add a new machine to your account. Run the &susemgr; Registration Client on the new machine you wish to add, and enter your existing &susemgr; username and password. The new machine is added to your existing account, and you can log into &susemgr; with your username and password to view all your systems simultaneously.

figure.title: Create a Unique Username and Password

sect1.para: Most users can leave the Org Info section blank. If you have an existing organization account, work with your &susemgr; administrator to ensure that your system is added to that account. This requires entering your organization's ID and password in the provided text fields. If the values are valid, the system is added to the organization's &susemgr; account. Your &susemgr; administrator can then create your user account through the Users category of the &susemgr; Web interface. Refer to for instructions.
Click Next to continue.

sect1.title: Registering a System Profile
sect1.para:
Now that you have a user account, you can create a system profile that consists of hardware and software information about your &sle; system. The software system profile information is used
to determine what software update notifications you receive.

sect2.title: Hardware System Profile
sect2.para: After creating a username and password for your &ncc; account, the &susemgr; Registration Client probes your system for the following information:

The next step is choosing a profile name for your system as shown in . The default value is the hostname for the system. You may modify this to be a more descriptive string, such as Email Server for Support Team. Optionally, you can enter a computer serial or identification number for the system.
If you do not wish to include information about your hardware or network in your system profile, deselect Include information about hardware and network (see ).
Click Next to continue with the registration process.

sect2.title: Software System Profile
sect2.para: The software system profile consists of a list of RPM packages for which you wish to receive notifications. The &susemgr; Registration Client displays a list of all RPM packages listed in the RPM database on your system and then allows you to customize the list by deselecting packages.

sect3.title: Gathering RPM Database Information
sect3.para: Only those packages you choose during this part of the registration are included in your system profile, and you will only receive notifications about the packages in your system profile. Thus, if you use an older version of a package and deselect it from the list, it will not be replaced with a newer version. This RPM list can be modified through the &susemgr; Web interface or by using the &susemgr; Update Agent. shows the progress bar displayed while the &susemgr; Registration Client gathers a list of the RPM packages installed on your system. This operation may take some time depending on your system.
Once the RPM package list is built, the list is displayed as shown in . Deselecting Include RPM Packages installed on this system in my System Profile omits this information from your system profile.

sect3.title: Choosing RPM Packages to Exclude from the System Profile
sect3.para: By default, all RPM packages in your RPM database are included in your system profile to be updated by Red Hat Network. To exclude a package, uncheck the package from the list by clicking the checkbox beside the package name. For example, shows that the procmail, procps, and psgml packages have been omitted from the package list.
Choose which packages to exclude, if any, from the system profile, and click Next to continue with the registration process.

figure.title: Choose which RPM Packages to Exclude from System Profile

sect1.title: Finishing Registration
sect1.para: As seen in , the last step of registration is to confirm that you want to send your System Profile to your &susemgr; server. If you choose Cancel at this point, no information is sent. Clicking Next submits your &susemgr; system profile. This process may take some time depending on your connection speed.

figure.title: Finished Collecting Information for System Profile

sect1.para: The &susemgr; Registration Client displays the Registration Finished screen ( once your System Profile has been sent successfully. Click Finish to exit the &susemgr; Registration Client.

After completing the registration, you must entitle your system to a
service level. Refer to for details.

sect1.title: Entitling Your System
sect1.remark: toms 2011-01-31: This seems to me more of NCC to me.
sect1.para: Now that you have registered your system, it must be entitled before you can receive updated packages. In other words, you must subscribe it to a service level offering.
To entitle a system, go to and log in using the same username and password you just used in the &susemgr; Registration Client.
